hint.text:
find the \(n^{th}\) term and use
Sum of an G.P. = \(a \frac {r^n-1}{r-1}\)
Then find \(S_n\) using following identities
\(\sum_1^n(n)=\frac{n(n+1)}{2}\)
\(\sum_1^n(n^2)=\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}\)
\(\sum_1^n(n^3)=\frac{\left(n(n+1)\right)^2}{4}\)

solution.text:
The \(n^{th}\) term of the given series is given
i.e.
\(a_n=n^2+_{p}_^n\)
now summing this from 1 to n we will get the sum
\(S_n=\sum_1^n a_n= \sum_1^n(n^2+_{p}_^n)\)
\(S_n=\sum_1^n(n^2)+\sum_1^n_{p}_^n\) .....(1)
also we know
\(\sum_1^n(n^2)=\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}\)
second term of the \(S_n\) is the sum of a G.P. whose first term and ratio are _{p}_
i.e
\(\sum_1^n_{p}_^n = _{p}_\frac{_{p}_^n-1}{_{p}_-1}\)
substitution this in equation (1), we will get
\(S_n=\frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6}+_{p}_\frac{_{p}_^n-1}{_{p}_-1}\)
Now putting n=_{s}_
\(S_ {_{s}_}=\frac{_{{s*(s+1)*((2*s)+1)}}_}{6}+_{p}_\frac{_{{(p**s)-1}}_}{_{{p-1}}_}\)
\(S_ {_{s}_}=_{{(s*(s+1)*((2*s)+1))/6}}_+_{{(((p**s)-1)*p)/(p-1)}}_\)
\(S_ {_{s}_}=_{{(s*(s+1)*((2*s)+1))/6 + (((p**s)-1)*p)/(p-1)}}_\)

content.text: Find the sum to _{s}_ terms of the series whose \(n^{th} \) term is given by \(n^2+_{p}_^n\)
